elts a Way We Have in the U.S.A.
Just as America's spiritual
greatness is founded on individual
freedom, so is our material greatness founded
on our unique system of free enterprise.
In this country we have demonstrated that
free competition in industry can produce
the highest standard of living and the great-
est concentration of
material
resources
known to the world.
But in times like these normal competition
quickly gives way to complete co-operation.
When our cherished way of life is threatened
our great industries pool their vast resources
and their vital supply of skilled man-power
to accomplish more quickly the tasks for
which they are peculiarly fitted.
This is a way we have in the U.S. A.—a way
that is both confusing and demoralizing to
our enemies.
Today the many commercial airlines, nor-
mally competitive, are working together on
the vital task of speeding our war effort. To
this common purpose the air transportation
industry is devoting its entire resources in
materials and men.
Transcontinental e Western Air, Inc.
TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL
Airline

YOU MAY TAKE THIS PACKET WITH

desire a souvenir of your journey.

AIR MAPS ARE LIKE ROAD MAPS
Map experts, cooperating with TWA's Navigation Department,
have taken great care to make these maps helpful and accurate
in every detail. Points of interest can be easily identified, help-
ing passengers orient themselves and pass the time pleasantly.
We hope you, as TWA's guest, will enjoy this presentation of
the nation's shortest, fastest coast-to-coast air route. If you wish,
YOU may keep this air map and log as a souvenir ot your trip.

(TWA
TRANSCONTIMENTAL

TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL

For
Your Guidance
A recent statement by the Civil Aeronautics
Board clarifies the position of the airlines in
the Nation's War Effort. There has been con-
fusion on this subject, hence the CAB state-
ment released on May 22, 1942, is laid out
below for vour information and guidance
Status of the Airlines
"The recent announcement by the War Depart-
ment made in connection with the President's
directive for a further coordination and integra-
an of domestic air transportation with the
iies of the military service, illustrates the truth
expressed by the President on January 24, 1939,
when he asserted that:
'The countr's welfare in time of beace and
ils safety in time of war rests upon * * *
economically and technically sound air transporta-
won system.
"The President's recent directive contemplates
the transfer of a substantial portion of the avail.
able flight equipment to Army air forces to be
operaled by the varions services and commands of

the Army; the conversion of a substantial number
of ships into cargo carriers to be operated by air-
line personnel under contract for the Air Service
Command; and the use of the remainder of the
equipment (about one-balf of the present supply
of the domestic lines) by the airlines in the con-
tinuance of their regular scheduled operations;
subject to their availability for military missions in
emergencies. Routes and schedules in airline oper
ation which are regarded as essential to the
war effort will be terminated to make possible the
highest utilization of the reduced equipment which
is available to the airlines. Air travel vital to the
country's needs will continue, subject to the
enforcement of a strict system of briorities.
Availability of Serviee
"The facts as stated make clear the error in
the press reports of the last few days which
announced that operation of the airlines had
been taken over by the War Department. While
the scheduled airline services have been limited pri-
marily to the war purposes and arrangements have
been made for a closer adaptation of those services
to the war needs, and while the number of schedules
have been substantially curtailed and in some in-
stances routes suspended the airlines will continue
to render service under their certificates of
public convenience and necessity and in accord-
ance with the regulatory authority of the Civil
Aeronautics Act. The whole-hearted fashion
in which the air carriers have cooperated with
the military services in furtherance of the war
effort bas made it possible for them to continue
operating under private management ever
though they now constitute essentially an arm
of the national defense.
"Thas, the CAB and its staff are assured that
their work has become tied in more closely than
ever before with the war effort. They have already
taken an active and major part in close cooperation
with the Military Director of Civil Aviation, in
the development and the plans for putting into
early effect the President's directive, and will con-
tinue to discharge those regulatory functions pre-
scribed by the Civil Aeronantics Act which are
even more necessary in war than in peace." (Note-
the captions and bold italics are our own.)
Please note the following:
1. The airlines continue to operate regu-
lar schedules with equipment not
transferred to the
Army.
2. Air travel vital to the country's needs
will continue, subject to the enforce-
ment ot priorities
3. The airlines continue their operation
as such and have not been taken over
by the War Department.
While the airlines "now constitute essen-
tally an arm of the national defense." and
schedules have been set up to serve essential
traffic flow, space available will be reserved
on request subject to priority of national de-
fense traffic movement. We suggest your
continuing to call our reservations depart-
ment who will be happy to keep you accurately
advised concerning availability ot space on
our schedules to all points.

Priority regulations provide for the estab
lishment of priority rating for essential civilian
travel by air. Where individuals and firms
are directly engaged in the war effort they
may be entitled to such rating. Any of our
offices will, on request, direct you to the
proper official channels for determination of
your priority status.
TWA
TRANSCONTINENTAL
Arline

Just as America's spiritual
greatness is founded on individual
freedom, so is our material greatness founded
on our unique system of free enterprise.
In this country we have demonstrated that
free competition in industry can produce
the highest standard of living and the great-
est concentration of material resources
known to the world.
But in times like these normal competition
quickly gives way to complete co-operation.
When our cherished way of life is threatened
our great industries pool their vast resources
and their vital supply of skilled man-power
to accomplish more quickly the tasks for
which they are peculiarly fitted.
This is a way we have in the U.S. A. -a way
that is both confusing and demoralizing to
our enemies.
Today the many commercial airlines, nor-
mally competitive, are working together on
the vital task of speeding our war effort. To
this common purpose the air transportation
industry is devoting its entire resources in
materials and men.
